He points out that there have been progress in increasing access to education in Pakistan, since the number of children outside the school has decreased from 25 million to 22 million according to government data. However, there is more to do. Without compromising access to school, the approach must be to improve quality. The assignment of the education budget is now 3.02% of GDP, compared to 2.83% last year, but it is not yet aim. The negative side of the situation is that 19% of children 6 to 16 are still out of school. The remaining 81% that is registered at the age level of 6-16 is not learning much either. The seventh report of the ASER survey also stood out according to the previous trends that children enrolled in private schools work better compared to those who study in government schools. The number of children outside the school must be a matter of concern for the entire nation and especially for federal and provincial governments. It is quite obvious that poverty is the main cause that keeps children away from schools and forces them to do some work to help complement their families' income. The problem can be addressed to a large extent if the number of government schools increases significantly. Government schools charge little or no fee, but these are not enough to meet the needs of the growing population. The distance factor and the participation of unbearable travel expenses also prohibit parents to send their children to schools. Private schools have multiplied both in urban and rural areas and are attending to the need for average and high income segments of society, but poor families cannot afford their children to admit in these schools. Its owners must also realize that they also have social and national obligations and offer some percentage of total admissions to the students of the poorest families of poor families. A characteristic of the kitchen book is that it offers glimpses of the Caribbean history that illustrate how historical events have dictated the food and dishes found in today's tables. Each dish can be seen as windows in the colorful history of the islands. These glimpses also illustrate that modern Caribbean cuisine is an eclectic mixture of cooking crops and techniques of all the main kitchens in the world. The reason is simple: during the last 500 years, the islands were visited by waves of conquerors, explorers, buccaneers, pirates, merchants and missionaries who were native, Spanish Indians, owners of British lands, African slaves, Chinese and oriental and Dutch Indians Irish, French, Germans, Jews, Libanese, Libanese, Portuguese, Portuguese and Scottish. All have contributed their food, spices and cooking methods, which over time have merged and combined to become a bold and unique kitchen.
